Business leaders have warned they need immigrants to fill vacancies, as Prime Minister Theresa May confirmed the Conservative manifesto will repeat a promise to get net migration below 100,000. 
The Tories first promised in 2010 to get net migration, the difference between the number of people coming in to the country and the number leaving, into the tens of thousands. 
But the Government has failing to live up this pledge, and latest figures showed net migration dropped to 273,000 in the year to September, the first time in two years the balance of people arriving and leaving the UK dipped below 300,000. Prime Minister Theresa May (Photo: PA) 
Mrs May has now confirmed that the promise will continue to be Conservative policy going in to the General Election . 
But the North East England Chamber of Commerce (NEECC) urged Ministers to consider the needs of the region, and highlighted the benefits overseas students bring to North East universities. 
Paul Carbert, NEECC policy adviser, said: “Our members want to see flexible migration rules that allow businesses in our region to retain and compete for highly skilled overseas talent. 
“Building and maintaining our overseas links is a key priority to help create a Global North East. Our five world-class universities attract international students and staff who bring enormous economic, societal and cultural benefits to the region, and this must not be put under threat by Government attempts to reduce net migration.” Northumbria University (Photo: Newcastle Chronicle) 
The Institute of Directors, which represents smaller businesses, also issued a warning. 
Stephen Martin, its director general, said: “A target is a poor substitute for a proper immigration policy. 
“All parties should instead see Brexit as an opportunity to come up with a new system that is good for the economy, but also addresses voters’ concerns.” 
Mr Martin called for better training for young people so they can get jobs in developing industries, as well as the removal of international students from official migration figures. 
The Prime Minister said it was important to hit this target given the pressure immigration had put on public services and those on lower incomes. 
Mrs May said: “I think it is important that we continue, and we will continue, to say that we do want to bring net migration down to sustainable levels. 
“We believe that is the tens of thousands, and of course once we leave the European Union we will have the opportunity to ensure that we have control of our borders here in the UK, because we’ll be able to establish our rules for people coming from the European Union into the UK.” 
She added: “That’s a part of the picture that we haven’t been able to control before and we will be able to control it. 
“Leaving the EU means that we won’t have free movement as it has been in the past.” Border Force check the passports of passengers arriving at Gatwick Airport (Photo: Getty Images Europe) 
Conservative sources had earlier said the commitment would appear in the party’s General Election manifesto. 
It follows comments by Home Secretary Amber Rudd over the weekend in which she appeared to suggest the Government could soften its migration policy. 
Mrs Rudd said on Sunday she wanted to “continue to bring immigration down” but stopped short of guaranteeing that the target would be repeated. 
Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn said his party would set out its immigration policy next week. 
He promised a “fair” and managed immigration system that “works for all”, while pointing out many immigrants have made a “massive contribution” to the NHS, education, industry and public transport services. Read More
